717679f-a.text:
The Belnord, Broadway, east side, from 86th to 87th Streets.
About 1911.
Gift of E. M. Jenks.

The Belnord was designed in 1908 by the noted architectural firm of Hiss and Weekes. It is 13 stories tall and features Italian Renaissance style decorative elements. It features two massive, two story grand archways that provide entrance to an inner courtyard with landscaped gardens.

The Belnord is one of a mere handful of full-block apartment buildings in New York. Like other full-block buildings, such as The Apthorp, the Belnord is built around a large, landscaped interior courtyard.The Belnord's courtyard is among the largest in the city.

717680f-a.text:
The Belnord, Broadway, west side, from 86th to 87th Streets.
1921.  South side from Broadway to Amsterdam Ave.
Gift of E. M. Jenks.
NEG2~S02E

714736f-a.text:
West 86th Street, east from but not including Broadway and showing Amsterdam Ave. intersecting (foreground). At the N.E. corner of the latter
is the West Park Pres. Church.

W.P.A. Photo.

714737f-a.text:
West 86th Street, south side, east from Broadway. Intersection shown
in the foreground is Amsterdam Ave.

714739f-a.text:
West 86th Street, west from and including Broadway to the North (Hudson) River showing in the foreground W.P.A. employees engaged in a work program on the block between Amsterdam Ave. and Broadway.  Shown on the right are the twin 7-story  units of Euclid Hall; an apartment house bearing Nos. 2343-2345 Broadway and occupying the entire block front on Broadway from 86th to 85th Streets.

November 10, 1936

W.P.A. Photo
Federal Art Project.
